oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nectria galligena as the cause of a collar rot disease in organically grown Topaz apple trees
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Weber, Roland W. S.
Klopp, Karsten
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Crop health, quality, protection
Fruit and berries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Symptoms resembling collar rot were detected in organically managed Topaz trees aged 3-10 years, occur-ring one to several years after planting of the orchard. Trees were killed within the same growing season in which symptoms were first observed. The disease commonly progressed as a complete covered canker at the base of the tree trunk. Isolation attempts were negative for Phytophthora and other Oomycetes, but con-sistently yielded Nectria galligena. The possibility of latent (endophytic) infections of N. galligena as the cause of delayed collar rot symptoms is briefly discussed.
